title: 115_s943
content: The Act titled "Johnson-O'Malley Supplemental Indian Education Program Modernization Act" updates the Indian Education Program by defining terms like contracting party and eligible entity. It also introduces the JOM Modernization Act. The Johnson-O'Malley Supplemental Indian Education Program Modernization Act defines terms like new contracting party and Secretary of the Interior. The Act also outlines the process for determining the number of eligible Indian students served by each eligible entity. The Act defines terms and outlines the process for determining eligible Indian students served by each entity using accurate data from the preceding fiscal year. The Act requires the Secretary to reconcile data with existing contracting parties and tribal enrollment information to improve the accuracy of the preliminary report before publishing. The Secretary must establish a 60-day comment period for feedback on the preliminary report from eligible entities. A final report on the number of eligible Indian students served by each entity must be published within 120 days after consultation. For subsequent academic years, determinations will be made to determine the number of eligible Indian students served by contracting parties. The Secretary determines the number of eligible Indian students served by contracting parties based on reported counts. Contracting parties must submit a report on eligible Indian students served and funds expended, failure to comply results in no funding for the following fiscal year. The Secretary provides contracting parties with reporting deadlines and consequences for non-compliance. Technical assistance is offered for compliance. An annual report includes student counts, funding recommendations, and contract assessments for budget requests. An annual report with student counts, funding recommendations, and contract assessments is submitted to specific committees and made publicly available. The report is prepared to prevent new administrative burdens on contracting parties. An initial hold harmless provision ensures existing contracting parties do not receive reduced funding, except under specific circumstances. Existing contracting parties will not receive less funding under the JOM Modernization Act compared to the previous fiscal year, unless specific conditions are met. Under the JOM Modernization Act, existing contracting parties may face funding reductions if they fail to report, violate contracts or laws, or experience a decrease in the number of eligible Indian students served. Under the JOM Modernization Act, existing contracting parties may face funding reductions if they report decreased student counts. The reduction cannot result in less funding per eligible Indian student than the previous fiscal year. If funds are insufficient, the Secretary will ratably reduce amounts for all parties. This provision will expire 4 years after the enactment of the Act. Under the JOM Modernization Act, funding per eligible Indian student cannot decrease by more than 10% from the previous fiscal year. The Secretary may recommend legislation to increase funding per student to 1995 levels and identify additional funding sources. Increases in program funding are subject to certain conditions. The JOM Modernization Act ensures that funding per eligible Indian student cannot decrease by more than 10% from the previous fiscal year. Excess funds are allocated to contracting parties that did not receive their full per student funding allocation in the previous year, with priority given to new contracting parties. After the first fiscal year of full funding allocation, parity in funding is maintained. The Secretary is required to consult with Indian tribes and educational agencies to increase geographical and tribal participation in the Johnson-O'Malley Supplementary Education Program. The JOM Modernization Act requires the Secretary to consult with Indian tribes and educational agencies to increase participation in the Johnson-O'Malley Supplementary Education Program. The Act also mandates a rulemaking process to clarify eligibility requirements and funding formulas for contracting parties. The JOM Modernization Act mandates a rulemaking process to ensure full participation of contracting parties, modernize rules, and protect student privacy. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress on the results and recommendations for implementation. The Comptroller General must submit a report 18 months after the final report to assess the Act's effectiveness. The Comptroller General is required to conduct a review of the implementation of the JOM Modernization Act, focusing on factors affecting accuracy of determinations, communication between parties, and funding distribution for Indian students. A report on the review results must be submitted to specific Senate and House committees.
